title: Hearing & Tinnitus Info Hub
subtitle: A practical, science-based guide for people with ringing, hissing, pulsing, fullness, sound sensitivity, or hearing loss.
urgentCare: When to Seek Urgent Care (Same day if possible)
urgentItem1: Sudden hearing loss in one ear (over hours to ≤3 days), with or without tinnitus/vertigo
urgentItem2: Neurologic signs (face droop/weakness, numbness, severe headache, double vision)
urgentItem3: Pulsatile tinnitus (sound in sync with heartbeat), especially new/worsening
urgentItem4: Ear pain, fever, drainage, or post-head injury hearing change
urgentNote: If in doubt, treat as urgent and arrange medical assessment.
linkNice: Hearing Loss in Adults – NICE NG98 (UK)
cause1: Noise-induced hearing loss, age-related loss, earwax, otitis, ototoxic meds, TMJ, stress/anxiety
steps1: Check earwax; review meds; basic hearing screen; protect from loud sound
cause2: Vascular causes, high BP, anemia, thyroid disease, middle-ear myoclonus
steps2: Measure BP; medical eval; consider imaging per clinician
cause3: Hyperacusis, migraine spectrum, anxiety, noise overexposure
steps3: Reduce overprotection, gradual sound enrichment, CBT-based support
cause4: Eustachian tube dysfunction, allergies, barotrauma, Ménière's
steps4: Auto-insufflation (gently), treat nose/allergy, medical exam if persistent
conditionTinnitusDesc: A sound no one else hears—often ringing, hissing, whistling. Frequently linked to hearing-pathway changes after noise exposure, aging, or middle-ear issues. Anxiety, poor sleep, and stress can amplify it.
conditionPulsatileDesc: A rhythmic sound in time with your heartbeat. Needs medical evaluation to rule out vascular/middle-ear causes. Work-up may include targeted imaging based on exam.
conditionHyperacusisDesc: Everyday sounds feel too loud or painful. Often co-occurs with tinnitus, migraine spectrum, or anxiety. Care focuses on graded sound exposure, counseling, and avoiding constant earplug use in safe environments.
conditionMenieresDesc: Spells of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and ear fullness (classically unilateral). Salt moderation, trigger management, and specialist care are typical.
conditionSsnhlDesc: Rapid inner-ear hearing drop (usually one ear) over ≤72 hours. This is an emergency. Early audiometry and evidence-based treatment (often steroids) improve odds of recovery.
conditionNihlDesc: From loud concerts, tools, gunfire, or long-term headphone overuse. Prevention (limits + protection) is key; hearing aids help when loss occurs.
conditionPresbycusisDesc: Gradual high-frequency hearing decline; speech sounds less clear, especially in noise. Modern hearing aids and communication strategies help.
conditionEtdDesc: Ear pressure/fullness, popping, muffled hearing, often after colds/allergies or flights. Treat nose/allergy; autoinflation; specialist if persistent.
conditionOtotoxicDesc: Some antibiotics (e.g., aminoglycosides), chemotherapy (e.g., cisplatin), loop diuretics, high-dose salicylates/NSAIDs, and others can cause tinnitus or hearing loss. Never stop a prescribed drug without medical advice.
whatHelpsTinnitus1: Education + reassurance: Tinnitus is a common brain/ear signal—severity often improves when you understand it
whatHelpsTinnitus2: Address hearing loss: Hearing aids can reduce tinnitus intrusiveness by restoring input
whatHelpsTinnitus3: Sound therapy/enrichment: Low-level ambient sound especially at night
whatHelpsTinnitus4: CBT-based approaches: Reduce distress, improve sleep and quality of life
whatHelpsTinnitus5: Sleep & stress care: Treat insomnia/anxiety; exercise and mindfulness help
whatHelpsHyperacusis1: Graded exposure + sound enrichment (do not live in earplugs)
whatHelpsPulsatile1: Check blood pressure, anemia, thyroid, pregnancy, new meds
whatHelpsPulsatile3: Treat the cause (e.g., BP control, venous stenosis stenting, etc.)
dailyTactics1: Protect, don't isolate: Use hearing protection for truly loud settings (concerts, tools), but avoid constant plug use in normal sound
dailyTactics2: Volume hygiene: 60/60 rule for headphones (≤60% volume, ≤60 minutes at a time)
dailyTactics3: Sleep routine: Regular schedule, lower caffeine late, wind-down audio at low level
dailyTactics4: Medication review: Ask your clinician to check for ototoxic risks
dailyTactics5: Track patterns: Log tinnitus loudness vs. stress, sleep, BP, caffeine, salt, alcohol
glossaryHyperacusis: Hyperacusis: Painful/irritating loudness of everyday sounds
glossaryPulsatile: Pulsatile tinnitus: Tinnitus in time with the heartbeat
disclaimer: Disclaimer: This guide is for education, not personal medical advice. If you have red-flag symptoms or worsening issues, seek in-person care promptly.
